{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3332069,"name":"","username":"Jugular","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/9d8465/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-13T15:33:47.340Z","cooked":"

My team is using a rev color sensor to detect when a note is in our intake. We were able to make it work with our intake, but after extending the wire so it could be attached to the end of out arm where the intake was, we couldn’t get the distance values from the rev color sensor. The led still turns on so could it be that the sensor doesn’t work if the wires are to long?

When you say extending the wire - what does that mean? I2C should be about 1 metre max But that depends - are your wires shielded? Twisted? What gauge wire did you use? Is there interference (too close to a motor perhaps).

The 1 meter max is about right and if you are trying to coax a tiny bit more then keep the SDA and SCl as far apart as possible. From my team wiring guide compiled from resources found on the Internet: Round cable put them on the diagonal and not adjacent. Flat cable put them on the edges.

We got it fixed. Looks like our extension using wagos kinda sucked. Got I soldered and how it works. But now we have I2C lockups so we just gonna trash the sensor and go with a simple beam break.

My team found the MXP I2C port worked fine for one device (failed with multiple devices). Not a bad idea to not use onboard or MXP (try the coprocessor recommended). We like the Pololu Sharp proximity sensors and there are many others posted recently on CD.

I was going to ask you to send us the color sensors if you are trashing them, then I remembered we have a drawer full of them already. Save them for using with the Pico. Known Issues — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
